The central hole is approximately 0.5 units in diameter. `<part_1>`: Create the base of the prism Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] - Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.1973, 0.0] Create a 2D sketch on the XY plane of the coordinate system. Draw a rectangle with the following line segments (loops consist of multiple lines): - Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.1973, 0.0] - Line 2: Start Point [0.1973, 0.0], End Point [0.1973, 0.1973] - Line 3: Start Point [0.1973, 0.1973], End Point [0.0, 0.1973] - Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.1973], End Point [0.0, 0.0] Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.1973. Transform the 2D sketch into 3D by rotating it around the Z-axis by -90 degrees and translating it along the Y-axis by 0.1973 units. Extrude the 2D sketch to a depth of 0.1973 units towards the normal and 0 units away from the normal. The sketch scaling factor is set to 0.1973. `<part_2>`: Create the central hole in the prism Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] - Translation Vector: [0.2859, 0.0195, 0.0] Create a 2D sketch on the XY plane of the new coordinate system. Draw the central hole as an open profile with the following line segments (loops consist of multiple lines): - Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.2188], End Point [0.1758, 0.0964] - Line 2: Start Point [0.1758, 0.0964], End Point [0.2291, 0.0] - Line 3: Start Point [0.2291, 0.0], End Point [0.3967, 0.0] - Line 4: Start Point [0.3967, 0.0], End Point [0.2715, 0.0561] - Line 5: Start Point [0.2715, 0.0561], End Point [0.2356, 0.2188] - Line 6: Start Point [0.2356, 0.2188], End Point [0.0, 0.2188] Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.3967. Transform the 2D sketch into 3D by applying the euler angles and translation vector from the coordinate system. Extrude the 2D sketch to a depth of 0.0395 units towards the normal and 0 units away from the normal. The sketch scaling factor is set to 0.3967. By following these instructions, the designer should be able to create the desired CAD model. The instructions are provided without any additional assumptions and focus solely on constructing the desired shape. The height, width, and length of each intermediate part and the final shape are derived from the JSON object.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Begin by creating a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to 0.0, 0.0, -90.0 degrees, and the translation vector to 0.0, 0.5, 0.0. This will orient your sketching plane correctly. Create a new sketch and draw a single face (face_1). Begin with the first line (line_1), starting at 0.0, 0.0, and ending at 0.75, 0.0. Follow it with the second line (line_2), starting at 0.75, 0.0, and ending at 0.75, 0.625. Continue by drawing the third line (line_3), moving from 0.75, 0.625 to 0.0, 0.625, and end with drawing the fourth line (line_4), going from 0.0, 0.625 back to 0.0, 0.0. Close the loop_1, which should now consist of 4 lines. Apply no additional constraints, as the loop should be closed by default. Since there is only a single loop on this face, no further action is required. Extrude the sketch to generate the 3D model by setting the extrusion depths: "extrude_depth_towards_normal" to 0.5 and "extrude_depth_opposite_normal" to 0.0. Scale the sketch using the specified parameter in the CAD assembly JSON: "sketch_scale" to 0.75. You have now created the first part for the final shape, a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The shape has dimensions 0.75 (length) by 0.5 (width) by 0.75 (height). The output should match the "CAD Assembly JSON" provided, maintaining agreed-upon accuracy and formatting standards for further processing and manufacturing. Next Part Continue generating detailed instructions for the next part and all subsequent parts as necessary. This will enable the junior CAD designer to produce an accurate CAD model that meets the project's requirements. Always remember to begin each section by describing the shape being constructed, using natural language descriptions for the boolean operation.</description>
